definition[0]: to fasten something, usually with a key, so that other people cannot open it, or to be fastened like this
example[1]: I can’t get this drawer to lock.
definition[1]: to put something in a place and fasten the door, lid etc with a key
example[2]: Lock the cat in the kitchen.
definition[2]: to become fixed in one position and impossible to move, or to make something become fixed
example[4]: A moment later they were locked in an embrace  (=holding each other very tightly in a loving or friendly way).
example[5]: Their eyes locked together  (=they could not look away from each other) for an instant.
example[6]: He locked his hands around the younger man’s throat.
definition[3]: if you are locked in a situation, you cannot get out of it
example[7]: The two groups are locked in a vicious cycle of killing.
example[8]: The company is locked into a five-year contract.
explanation[0]: Lock is usually passive in this meaning
definition[4]: a thing that keeps a door, drawer etc fastened and is usually opened with a key or by moving a small metal bar
example[9]: I’m sorry, there isn’t a lock on the bathroom door.
example[10]: The key turned stiffly in the lock.
definition[5]: a small number of hairs on your head that grow and hang together
example[12]: He gently pushed a lock of hair from her eyes.
definition[7]: a part of a canal or river that is closed off by gates so that the water level can be raised or lowered to move boats up or down a slope
definition[8]: a hold which wrestlers use to prevent their opponent from moving
definition[9]: the degree to which a vehicle’s front wheels can be turned in order to turn the vehicle
definition[10]: a playing position in the game of rugby
definition[11]: if two people or organizations lock horns, they start being involved in a serious disagreement or struggle with each other
example[15]: Mr. Lorenzo locked horns with union representatives in his efforts to turn around the struggling business.
definition[12]: if two people or organizations are locked in a battle, they are involved in a serious disagreement or struggle against each other
example[16]: The two networks are locked in a close ratings battle.
example[17]: The unions are locked in difficult negotiations with the company.
definition[13]: to have complete control of something
example[18]: The firm now has an 85% lock on the market.
example[19]: Between them the two airlines have a virtual lock on domestic air traffic.
example[20]: These currency controls put a lock on Pakistan’s dealings with the larger world.
